Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: I was standing in my apartment hallway, leash in hand, as my dog barked loudly at the sound of footsteps near the shared door. Mrs. Lee from next door shot me a tired look, and I felt the weight of her unspoken expectation: keep the noise down, respect our shared space. I mumbled an apology, tugging my dog back inside, heart pounding with embarrassment. Just as I closed the door, my phone buzzed—a reminder from my activist group. The online petition to strengthen animal welfare laws was about to be sent to our local legislator, and I had one last chance to add my name. My activist side screamed that I couldn’t miss this opportunity to make a difference. But I hesitated, thinking of Mrs. Lee and the other neighbors who already seemed frustrated with my dog’s outbursts. If I signed, my name would be public, and I worried they’d see me as someone who cared more about causes than about being a good neighbor. My thumb hovered over the screen, torn between the expectations of my community and my commitment to advocacy, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in.
